snippet: IN 1921, Dr. Lewis M. Terman, a Stanford University psychologist and a pioneer of the I.Q. test, scoured California's schools to identify 1,521 children who scored 135 or over on his new intelligence test, the Stanford-Binet.   Terman's little gen...
lead_paragraph: IN 1921, Dr. Lewis M. Terman, a Stanford University psychologist and a pioneer of the I.Q. test, scoured California's schools to identify 1,521 children who scored 135 or over on his new intelligence test, the Stanford-Binet. Terman's little geniuses -- who as the study went on took to calling themselves "Termites" -- are now in their 80's, and have been contacted by researchers every 5 or 10 years, making the Terman Study of Genius the grandfather of all life-span research.

headline.main: 75 Years Later, Study Still Tracking Geniuses
